--- Comment #2 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
I don't think paste() should be handled specially - it is a function in R with
standard argument matching. The problem that misspelled argument names may
accidentally be matched by "..." is in principle general to functions accepting
named arguments after "..." - this is not special to paste(). Even though, with
some functions, this would be more likely result of an error than with other.

Right, perhaps this could be flagged, for selected functions, by some linting
or code checking tools maintained outside of base R. One could imagine in such
tools to only warn when the edit distance from a named formal argument is
small.

But I don't think base R should be doing this.

*[Bug 16183] LDFLAGS overrides PKG_LIBS*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=16183>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|NEW                         |CLOSED
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
         Resolution|---                         |Works as documented

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
The current behavior when LDFLAGS precede PKG_LIBS, and hence -L flags from
LDFLAGS (if any) override PKG_LIBS, has been in R for very long and users have
at least indirectly gotten used to that. I think it is a valid design decision
and I don't see a strong reason for changing it and causing the inevitable
disruption by that. Moreover, such disruption would be hard to prevent by
testing - because it would depend on what the users were doing on their systems
(how they set LDFLAGS). And yet more, the current behavior is reasonably
simple: all of LDFLAGS precede all of PKG_LIBS - a mixture would be more
complicated to debug problems with.

The current design has the advantage that the administrator or power user or
software distribution maintainer can override some low-level library used in
the packages (well, so, in other words, the current behavior can be seen as
advantage...).

Also, nobody from the core team has supported this idea in the last 10 years.

text:
*[Bug 17357] Reflect propagation from integer to numeric in class attribute for length(class(obj)) > 1*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=17357>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
         Resolution|---                         |Works as documented

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
I think it would not be possible to change this, it would be a big change in
the language design, which is not possible at this point, so this is a
theoretical discussion (and perhaps as such would be better suited to say
R-devel mailing list, or maybe even R-help). 

Unlike some other languages, R has multiple notions of a type, not just one
(The R Language Definition provides more details about this design). What the
class attribute contains is only a part of the story. This is something that
cannot be realistically changed.

class(1L) returns "integer", which is an implicit class in this case taken from
the "type" as in typeof(). There is no "class" attribute.

When one computes 1L/1.0, the result is a value of "type" (as in typeof())
double, again no class attribute is involved or even present.

Even when the class attribute is present, the default implementation of the
arithmetic operations ignores it, it works on the "type" as in typeof() (See R
Language Definition).

So,

structure(class=c("myclass", "character"), 1L)/10.0

still divides an integer (1L) by a double (10.0) and leaves the class attribute
alone. This could perhaps be even more surprising, but this is because the
class attributes are "above" the types of the values.

I would myself avoid using the implicit class names as explicit in the class
attribute to avoid confusion, and the R Language Definition warns against
modifying the class attribute directly.

Re the example in the original report,  "class(y2) # c("myclass", "integer") -
not propagated to c("myclass", "numeric")"

Not knowing R I would actually have expected something else. If using some
default method for dividing an integer by a numeric, I would expect the result
to be a plain "numeric" - how could the default method know about "myclass" nor
how could it create one?

Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) changed:

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CONFIRMED

     Ever confirmed|0                           |1

--- Comment #1 from Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) ---
I agree that `lbeta()` should also error for complex number inputs, the same
way as `beta()` and `gamma()` and `lgamma()` do.

Of course, we could envisage to provide the complex gamma function as well,
and from that derive the complex beta.  That would be another issue, and a
"wishlist" primarily.

Also, this has no immediate value to me nor application in stats I would know
of.

Still, as I just mentioned else where, I'm currently working on providing
`log1p()`  and  `expm1()`  working -- numerically stably! -- for complex
arguments.

I definitely do *not* need a patch to fix this.

Possibly someone could systematically check all functions in

```
> getGroupMembers("Math")
 [1] "abs"      "sign"     "sqrt"     "ceiling"  "floor"    "trunc"   
 [7] "cummax"   "cummin"   "cumprod"  "cumsum"   "exp"      "expm1"   
[13] "log"      "log10"    "log2"     "log1p"    "cos"      "cosh"    
[19] "sin"      "sinh"     "tan"      "tanh"     "acos"     "acosh"   
[25] "asin"     "asinh"    "atan"     "atanh"    "cospi"    "sinpi"   
[31] "tanpi"    "gamma"    "lgamma"   "digamma"  "trigamma"
```
... which interestingly, has never contained  `beta()` and  `lbeta()`.

Most "Math"-functions are documented to work with complex, notably `abs(.)`
(defined as `Mod(.)` already in S),
 `exp()` and  `log()`, but also all
trigonometric and "hyperbolic" functions including their inverses.

The list above will remind (some of) us, that indeed, `ceiling()`, `floor()`
and `trunc()`  could/should probably be implemented,
not trivially though because there's no complete ordering of complex numbers.

*[Bug 18085] File.remove*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18085>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED
         Resolution|---                         |WISHLIST
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com

--- Comment #4 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
Deleting via recycle bin is not something R could be changed to do by default,
e.g. in file.remove(). Maybe this is rather a case for external measures, such
as backup.

The biggest problem of potentially changing the default behavior to using
recycle bin is that files moved to the recycle bin still occupy disk space.
While it is possible to set up automated cleaning of the recycle bin, not all
systems would be set up like that and user programs would start running out of
disk space. Also, that files deleted by file.remove() are hard to restore and
cannot be reliably restored can sometimes been seen as an advantage, e.g. when
deleting sensitive data. User expectations would match the current behavior
when file.remove() is "permanent". 

Deleting files via a recycle bin, say on Windows and macOS, could be an
optional feature or a special deletion function. It could also support some
mode for Unix systems, perhaps as suggested, by moving to a temporary session
directory or implementing some custom recycle bin.

I don't think this should be in base R. Python has a module for this
(Send2Trash). Perhaps this is something what could be implemented in a package
for those who wish to use it.

Now, as such feature would have to be opt-in, anyway, perhaps one could also
establish a practice of using File Explorer when deleting important files
manually, rather than calling file.remove() from R.

*[Bug 18155] Allow calls of the form `pkg::object$name <- value`?*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18155>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
I don't think this should be allowed, certainly the examples didn't convince
me. One can define and export functions to access such a data structure. After
all, R options in base R are normally set via function options().

I don't think the proposed syntax would necessarily help readability of the
code. Also, it could invite expectations that one could change bindings in a
sealed namespace that way and lead to related errors. Using functions makes it
easier to encapsulate that (e.g. that there is a custom environment one is
modifying).

It is also possible to expose a function that would return such environment to
the user, and the user can then modify the environment the usual way.

--- Comment #6 from Elin Waring (<mailto:elin.waring@gmail.com|elin.waring@gmail.com>) ---
It's actually clear if you read the documentation carefully, but I think that
if the documentation is being revised it should warn that this is not to be
used for testng nested mdoels (because the degrees of freedom will not be
correct).  The presence of the formula method, in particular, makes this
confusing (in my opinion).

added as an example?

var.test(mpg ~ am, data = mtcars) # Use of formula when comparing exactly two
groups.

```
var.test(mpg ~ carb, data = mtcars) # Error with more than two levels.
```

Also the error message

>  grouping factor must have exactly 2 levels

Should possibly be changed to grouping variable rather than grouping factor to
avoid confusion.

*[Bug 18947] New: silhouette in cluster cause R to crash on Windows*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18947>

            Bug ID: 18947
           Summary: silhouette in cluster cause R to crash on Windows
           Product: R
           Version: R 4.5.x
          Hardware: x86_64/x64/amd64 (64-bit)
                OS: Windows 64-bit
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Windows GUI / Window specific
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:jszhao@yeah.net|jszhao@yeah.net>

On Windows, running the following code would cause R to crash, i.e. R quit
without any message. 

```
library(cluster)
data(ruspini)
cl <- sample(1:3, nrow(ruspini), replace = TRUE)
d <- as.dist(ruspini)
silhouette(cl, d)
```

If R is not crashed, run the last line of code repeatedly.

You may argue that `d` is not a right dist object. However, in this case,
`silhouette` should give a warning or error message instead of crashing
completely.

On FreeBSD system, the same code does not crash R.
